Traditional NLTK Sentiment Analysis¶

This analysis consists of a series of experiments using different feature sets to classify movie reviews using the Naive Bayes Classifier from the Natural Language Toolkit package. As a note to the reader, due to the random nature of the machine learning classifier and the shuffling of the data before training and testing are performed, running these experiments may lead to slightly different results. However, the conclusions made from each experiment will remain the same.

Before starting the analysis, the required packages are loaded.

In [1]:
#Loading required packages
import nltk
import pandas as pd
import re
import random
from textblob import TextBlob

Importing the Data¶

The movie reviews are sourced from the Kaggle Movie Reviews training data set in the form of a .tsv file. This file is read in and saved as a pandas DataFrame.

In [2]:
#Reading in the data set and saving as a data frame
review_df = pd.read_csv("FinalProjectData/kagglemoviereviews/corpus/train.tsv", sep = "\t")

This data frame consists of four columns. PhraseId is a unique identifier for the phrase contained in each row of the data frame. SentenceId identifies which review each phrase contained in the data frame belongs to. Phrase contains the actual text of each phrase of each review. Sentiment contains a value from 0 to 4 that is used to identify how positive or negative each phrase is.

  • A sentiment of 0 is negative.
  • A sentiment of 1 is somewhat negative.
  • A sentiment of 2 is neutral.
  • A sentiment of 3 is somewhat positive.
  • A sentiment of 4 is positive.
In [3]:
#Printing the column names of the data frame
print(review_df.columns)
#Printing the unique values of the Sentiment column
print(review_df["Sentiment"].unique())

Processing the Data¶

Now that each value of Phrase in the data frame contains a unique review, these reviews can be extracted to form the corpus that will be used in the sentiment analysis. An empty list is initialized and by looping over the entire data frame, each review contained in the Phrase column is appended to the list.

In [245]:
#Initializing an empty list to hold the reviews
review_list = []
#Looping over every row of the data frame and appending the review in the Phrase column to the review list
for i in range(len(unique_reviews)):
    review_list.append(unique_reviews["Phrase"][i])

The length of the review list matches the length of the data frame so all the reviews were successfully appended.

In [246]:
#Printing the length of the review list to ensure it matches the length of the data frame
print(len(review_list))
#Showing a preview of the first 10 reviews
print(review_list[:10])

One of the main features for the sentiment classifications involves finding the most common word tokens present among all the reviews. To accomplish this, we need to create a flattened list of every word token in the review list.

First, each review is tokenized separately at the word level. This creates a list of lists, where each sublist is the list of word tokens for that review.

In [8]:
#Applying the NLTK word_tokenizer function to each review in the review list
word_tokens_list = [nltk.word_tokenize(review) for review in review_list]

Now the list is flattened so that all the word tokens are contained in a single list. Viewing the first 40 word tokens shows that although the tokens from the second review have started being listed out that they are not grouped into their own sublist.

In [9]:
#Flattening the list of lists, so all the word tokens from all the reviews are contained in a single list
word_tokens_flat = [word for review in word_tokens_list for word in review]
#Showing the first 40 word tokens
print(word_tokens_flat[:40])

['A', 'series', 'of', 'escapades', 'demonstrating', 'the', 'adage', 'that', 'what', 'is', 'good', 'for', 'the', 'goose', 'is', 'also', 'good', 'for', 'the', 'gander', ',', 'some', 'of', 'which', 'occasionally', 'amuses', 'but', 'none', 'of', 'which', 'amounts', 'to', 'much', 'of', 'a', 'story', '.', 'This', 'quiet', ',']

To avoid a word with capitalization being considered a different word from when it is lower case, all the characters of all the word tokens are set to be lower case.

In [10]:
#Making all the word tokens in the flattened list entirely lowercase
words_lower = [word.lower() for word in word_tokens_flat]
#Showing the first 40 lowercase tokens
print(words_lower[:40])

['a', 'series', 'of', 'escapades', 'demonstrating', 'the', 'adage', 'that', 'what', 'is', 'good', 'for', 'the', 'goose', 'is', 'also', 'good', 'for', 'the', 'gander', ',', 'some', 'of', 'which', 'occasionally', 'amuses', 'but', 'none', 'of', 'which', 'amounts', 'to', 'much', 'of', 'a', 'story', '.', 'this', 'quiet', ',']

Finally, any punctuation or symbols are filtered out of the list of word tokens. This is done by defining and then applying the alpha_filter function to the list of word tokens. This function looks at each token to see if it does not contain alphabetic characters. If the token contains no alphabetic characters, that token is removed from the list.

In [11]:
#Defining the alpha_filter function. This function uses a regex expression to match any token that does not contain
# any alphabetic characters
def alpha_filter(w):
  pattern = re.compile('^[^a-z]+$')
  if (pattern.match(w)):
    return True
  else:
    return False

Looking at the first 40 word tokens after the filter has been applied shows that the punctuation has been removed

In [12]:
#Applying the alpha filter to each word token. If the token does not contain alphabetic characters it is removed
words_alpha = [word for word in words_lower if not alpha_filter(word)]
#Showing a preview of the first 40 filtered tokens
print(words_alpha[:40])

['a', 'series', 'of', 'escapades', 'demonstrating', 'the', 'adage', 'that', 'what', 'is', 'good', 'for', 'the', 'goose', 'is', 'also', 'good', 'for', 'the', 'gander', 'some', 'of', 'which', 'occasionally', 'amuses', 'but', 'none', 'of', 'which', 'amounts', 'to', 'much', 'of', 'a', 'story', 'this', 'quiet', 'introspective', 'and', 'entertaining']

Next, the lemmatization function from the NLTK package will be applied to the list of the word tokens. This shortens the words, similar to a stemming function, but the remaining word is an actual English word, which is not always the case when stemming. This is done so that forms of the same word, that may have a suffix for example, will be treated as the same word token.

In [13]:
#Alias the lemmatization function from the NLTK package
wnl = nltk.WordNetLemmatizer()

#Apply the lemmatization function to all the remaining tokens in Dracula
words_alpha = [wnl.lemmatize(word) for word in words_alpha]
#Preview the first 100 tokens
print(words_alpha[:40])

['a', 'series', 'of', 'escapade', 'demonstrating', 'the', 'adage', 'that', 'what', 'is', 'good', 'for', 'the', 'goose', 'is', 'also', 'good', 'for', 'the', 'gander', 'some', 'of', 'which', 'occasionally', 'amuses', 'but', 'none', 'of', 'which', 'amount', 'to', 'much', 'of', 'a', 'story', 'this', 'quiet', 'introspective', 'and', 'entertaining']

One can see an example of the lemmatization working in how "escapades" was shortened to "escapade".

The sentiment analyses will use the 2000 most frequent word tokens from the reviews. To find these, a frequency distribution is created using the flattened list of word tokens. The 2000 most common words from the frequency distribution are extracted and saved in a list called word_features.

In [14]:
#Creating a frequency distribution of all the word tokens in the words_alpha list
words_freq = nltk.FreqDist(words_alpha)
#Collecting the 2000 most common word tokens
word_items = words_freq.most_common(2000)
#Saving just the word tokens of the 2000 most frequent in a list
word_features = [word for (word, count) in word_items]
#Showing the first 40 word features
print(word_features[:40])

['the', 'a', 'and', 'of', 'it', 'to', 'is', "'s", 'that', 'in', 'film', 'but', 'with', 'movie', 'for', 'this', 'an', 'you', "n't", 'be', 'on', 'not', 'one', 'by', 'about', 'ha', 'more', 'are', 'at', 'like', 'from', 'than', 'all', 'have', 'his', 'i', 'so', 'if', 'story', 'or']

We now have each review as a sublist of word tokens contained within the list, but there is no information about what the sentiment of each review is. To fix this, we first initialize an empty list. Then for each review in the unique_reviews data frame, the lowercase tokenized version of each review and the corresponding sentiment of that review are joined together as a tuple and appended to that initialized list.

In [18]:
#Initializing an empty list
lower_reviews_sent = []
#Looping over every row of the unique_reviews data frame to join each tokenized review with its corresponding 
#Sentiment and creating tuples
for i in range(len(unique_reviews)):
    lower_reviews_sent.append((lower_reviews[i], unique_reviews["Sentiment"][i]))

#Showing a preview of the first tuple of tokenized review and sentiment value
print(lower_reviews_sent[:1])

[(['a', 'series', 'of', 'escapade', 'demonstrating', 'the', 'adage', 'that', 'what', 'is', 'good', 'for', 'the', 'goose', 'is', 'also', 'good', 'for', 'the', 'gander', ',', 'some', 'of', 'which', 'occasionally', 'amuses', 'but', 'none', 'of', 'which', 'amount', 'to', 'much', 'of', 'a', 'story', '.'], 1)]

Looking at the first review by itself above, one can see how the sentiment value of 1 is at the end of the tokenized review.

In the original data there are five different sentiments. This may be overly difficult for a classifier to figure out because there is a lot of nuance in how one would separate a "somewhat negative" review from a "negative" review. It is likely that given a group of people looking at a review, that they might disagree at how to classify a sentiment so granularly as well. For this reason, each classifier will be run using the original sentiments along with a modified group of sentiments. The modified group will contain only three sentiments: negative, neutral, and positive. To accomplish this the "somewhat" positive/negative reviews will be rolled in to an overall positive/negative category.

Returning to the unique_reviews data frame, we first make a copy of it.

In [19]:
#Creating a copy of the unique_review data frame for the purpose of recoding the Sentiment variable
three_sentiments = unique_reviews.copy()

To encode a new variable that will describe the sentiment of each review as one of only three categories, we first need to make a sentiment mapping dictionary. This mapping will set "somewhat negative" and "negative" to "negative", "neutral" to "neutral", and "somewhat positive" and "positive" to "positive".

  • A value of 1 is negative.
  • A value of 2 is neutral.
  • A value of 3 is positive.
In [20]:
#Creating a mapping that will recode the values of the Sentiment variable
sentiment_mapping = {0:1, 1:1, 2:2, 3:3, 4:3}

This mapping is applied to the Sentiment column in the data frame. Looking at the first 100 rows, one can see how there are no longer any values of 0 or 4, but just values of 1, 2, and 3.

In [21]:
#Applying the mapping to the sentiment column to change the values
three_sentiments = three_sentiments.assign(Sentiment = three_sentiments.Sentiment.map(sentiment_mapping))

#Showing a preview of the data frame to show the new sentiment values
three_sentiments[:100]

The data is now prepared for the various sentiment analysis experiments. Each experiment will focus on using different feature sets to classify the reviews. These feature sets will be generated twice. Once for the 5 sentiment classification and once for the 3 sentiment classification.

Experiment 1: Bag of Words Sentiment Classification¶

For this experiment, we will define feature sets where each feature is a true or false value depending on whether one of the 2000 most common word tokens is contained in that particular review.

The following function is used to create the feature sets.

In [27]:
#This function takes in the list of reviews and the set of word features and generates a feature set.
#The feature set is a series of True/False values based on the presence or absence of a word feature in a particular 
#review. A feature set is generated for each review individually.
def document_features(document, word_features):
    document_words = set(document)
    features = {}
    for word in word_features:
        features['V_{}'.format(word)] = (word in document_words)
    return features

Experiment 1A: Five Sentiments Bag of Words Classification¶

The bag of words feature sets function is applied to the shuffled list of reviews with the original 5 sentiments.

In [28]:
#Creating the feature set using the document_features function. Each feature set is the list of true/false values
#for each word token present or absent in the review, followed by its sentiment value
featuresets_bow = [(document_features(d, word_features), c) for (d, c) in lower_reviews_sent]

Looking at the first item in the feature set shows how it is created and the True/False values for the first review in the shuffled review list.

Each classification experiment will use a 90/10 training/testing split. First, we check the length of the feature set to see how many reviews there are in total.

In [30]:
#Finding the length of the feature set
len(featuresets_bow)
Out[30]:
8529

The length of the feature set is multiplied by 0.1 to see how many reviews make up 10% of the total.

In [31]:
#Finding how many feature sets make up 10% of the data
len(featuresets_bow)*.1
Out[31]:
852.9000000000001

The feature sets represent the data from the reviews that the classifier will be trained and tested on. The testing data will be comprised of the feature sets from the first 853 of the randomized reviews and the training data will be the rest. The Naive Bayes Classifier from the NLTK package is trained on the training set.

In [32]:
#Creating training and testing sets based on a 90/10 split of the feature sets data
train_set_bow, test_set_bow = featuresets_bow[853:], featuresets_bow[:853]
#Training the NLTK Naive Bayes Classifier on the training data
classifier_bow = nltk.NaiveBayesClassifier.train(train_set_bow)

The trained classifier is now tested on the testing data to see how accurate it is.

In [33]:
#Applying the trained classifier to the testing data to see how accurate it is at classifying the sentiment
nltk.classify.accuracy(classifier_bow, test_set_bow)
Out[33]:
0.42907385697538103

This model proved to not be very accurate with only about 43% accuracy. With 5 different sentiment categories, random guessing should achieve 20% accuracy in the long run so this is a large improvement, but overall this model would never be trusted to classify these reviews correctly.

The accuracy of the model can also be analyzed using a confusion matrix. The confusion matrix shows how many reviews the model classified right or wrong for each actual sentiment value. This is done by initializing two empty lists, where one will hold the predicted sentiment values from the classifier and one will hold the actual values from the data.

    goldlist_bow.append(label)
    predictedlist_bow.append(classifier_bow.classify(features))

Each row represents the reference, or actual values, and each column represents the predicted values from the model. This means that the model correctly identified 31 of the reviews that actually had a sentiment score of 0, which corresponds to "negative". The 0 column shows all the reviews the classifier said were negative and by looking at the row labels we can see what the actual sentiments of those predictions were. For example, this classifier thought 18 of the neutral reviews were negative.

Overall, the model got many more of the negative reviews wrong than it did right. It also got more of the neutral reviews wrong than right. It was best at correctly classifying the positive reviews, but did mistake a fair number of those with a score of 3 as having a score of 4 and those with a score of 4 as having a score of 3.

Instead of just looking at the accuracy of a single training and testing run, we can use k-fold cross validation to make sure the accuracy achieved was not overly high or low based on random chance. K-fold cross validation works by partitioning the data into training and testing data multiple times and running multiple accuracy evaluations. For example, if we use 10 folds, then the data is partitioned into 10 equal sized blocks. To start, the testing data will be chosen as the first block and the other 9 are used as training data. The model is trained and evaluated on this split. Then the second block is chosen as the testing data and again the other 9 are used as the training data. This process is repeated until each block has been used as the testing data for the accuracy evaluation of the model. After the k-fold cross validation finishes, there will be 10 accuracy values and by taking the mean of those we have a better picture of the "true" accuracy of the model.

The following code block defines the function that is used to run k-fold cross validation on the feature sets for a chosen number of folds.

In [37]:
#This function takes as its inputs the number of folds and the feature sets. The function iterates over each fold, 
#using the different blocks of data as training and testing, evaluating the model, and then printing the accuracy
#of each run.
def cross_validation_accuracy(num_folds, featuresets):
    subset_size = int(len(featuresets)/num_folds)
    print('Each fold size:', subset_size)
    accuracy_list = []
    #Iterating over each fold
    for i in range(num_folds):
        test_this_round = featuresets[(i*subset_size):][:subset_size]
        train_this_round = featuresets[:(i*subset_size)] + featuresets[((i+1)*subset_size):]
        #Training the classifier for each round of the loop
        classifier = nltk.NaiveBayesClassifier.train(train_this_round)
        #Evaluate the model using this round's testing data and report the accuracy
        accuracy_this_round = nltk.classify.accuracy(classifier, test_this_round)
        print (i, accuracy_this_round)
        accuracy_list.append(accuracy_this_round)
    #Take the mean of the accuracies from all rounds
    print ('mean accuracy', sum(accuracy_list) / num_folds)

The k-fold cross validation will be run using 10 folds. This is to keep it in line with the 90/10 training and testing data split used in the single evaluation.

In [38]:
#Setting the number of folds to 10
num_folds = 10
#Applying the cross validation accuracy function with the 10 folds and the feature set
cross_validation_accuracy(num_folds, featuresets_bow)

Each fold size: 852

The accuracy of the first evaluation of the model was actually overstated compared to the mean accuracy of the cross validation. The best guess at the "true" accuracy of the model is 5% less at 38%. It can been seen in the runs of the cross validation that sometimes the model does score a bit higher though as evidenced by the first 2 runs.

Accuracy is not always the best measure of the performance of a model. Imagine an extreme circumstance such as 95% of the reviews having a sentiment score of 1. If the model just predicts a sentiment of 1 every time without even really considering the features, then it would be 95% accurate, but the model would likely be extremely inaccurate when applied to a different set of data.

For this reason, we will also look at the values of precision, recall, and F1. Precision is the percent that the model correctly predicted out of all the predictions it made for a certain value. Recall is the percent that the model correctly predicted out of all the actual reviews with that value. The F1-measure is defined as the harmonic mean of precision and recall and is defined by the following formula:

F1 = 2(Recall * Precision) / (Recall + Precision)

The harmonic mean is a more suitable mean for this ratios than just the traditional mean.

The F1-measure provides a singular metric that weighs precision and recall in a balanced way. This means for the F1-measure to increase, both precision and recall need to increase.

There are many advantages to using the F1-measure instead of accuracy. First, the F1-measure provides a singular metric that weighs precision and recall in a balanced way. This means for the F1-measure to increase, both precision and recall need to increase. Second, if the data set is unbalanced (such as there are many more positive reviews than negative reviews), this metric provides a better balance across the categories. Lastly, this gives a single metric to evaluate the model on instead of several.

The following function calculates the recall, precision, and F1-measure for the model evaluation.

In [39]:
# This function takes the list of actual values and predicted values as its inputs. It initalizes lists to hold the
# precision, recall, and F1 scores and calculates each one for the various classification values.

def eval_measures(gold, predicted):
    #Getting a list of the labels
    labels = list(set(gold))
    #Initializing empty lists for metrics
    recall_list = []
    precision_list = []
    F1_list = []
    for lab in labels:
        #Compare True Positives, False Positives, False Negatives, and True Negatives to predict the metrics
        TP = FP = FN = TN = 0
        for i, val in enumerate(gold):
            if val == lab and predicted[i] == lab:  TP += 1
            if val == lab and predicted[i] != lab:  FN += 1
            if val != lab and predicted[i] == lab:  FP += 1
            if val != lab and predicted[i] != lab:  TN += 1
        #Calculate the metrics based on the above values
        recall = TP / (TP + FP)
        precision = TP / (TP + FN)
        recall_list.append(recall)
        precision_list.append(precision)
        F1_list.append( 2 * (recall * precision) / (recall + precision))
    #Print the results of each metric for each classification value per row
    print('\tPrecision\tRecall\t\tF1')
    #Printing the results
    for i, lab in enumerate(labels):
        print(lab, '\t', "{:10.3f}".format(precision_list[i]), \
          "{:10.3f}".format(recall_list[i]), "{:10.3f}".format(F1_list[i]))

Running the evaluation_measures function on the lists of predicted values and actual values generates the precision, recall, and F1 values. There is not a lack of data for any one of the sentiment categories so the accuracy measure of the classifer can be trusted, but these additional metrics provide a more in-depth look at the performance of the classifier.

In [40]:
#Running the eval_measures function to get the precision, recall, and F1 for each sentiment score

	Precision	Recall		F1
0 	      0.290      0.360      0.321
1 	      0.546      0.445      0.490
2 	      0.329      0.341      0.335
3 	      0.442      0.455      0.448
4 	      0.464      0.516      0.489

The set of reviews is not very unbalanced so it is not surprising that the F1-measures show the model performing poorly as well. Looking at these statistics shows that the model had the most trouble with neutral reviews and did the best with positive reviews.

The model got the highest proportion of "somewhat negative" reviews correct compared to all the reviews it thought were "somewhat negative". Also, the model got the highest proportion of "positive" reviews correct out of the total number of reviews that were "positive".

Experiment 2: Bag of Words and Review Length Classification¶

This experiment was inspired by the thought that people who do not like a movie might have more they want to say in a review than someone who did like a movie. If the length of the review is an informative feature for the classifier, then it could use that length to help predict the sentiments.

The document features function is modified to include the length of each review as one of the features along with the bag of words. By training and testing the classifier with this feature set we will see if the inclusion of length will affect the accuracy of the model.

In [48]:
#Creating the function to make a new featureset that includes the length of the review as a feature
def document_features_length(document, word_features):
    document_words = set(document)
    features = {}
    for word in word_features:
        features['V_{}'.format(word)] = (word in document_words)
    features['length'] = sum(len(word) for word in document_words)
    return features

Experiment 3: Bag of Words with Common Negation Words Classification¶

For this experiment, a list of common negation words will be defined and used to build a new set of features in the feature sets. These negation words are words that are frequently used to negate the meaning of the word or phrase following them. By placing an additional focus on the negated word features, the classifier may be able to better identify the negative reviews and not mistake them as being neutral.

In [63]:
#List of negation words and approximate negation words
negationwords = ['no', 'not', 'never', 'none', 'nowhere', 'nothing', 'noone', 'rather', 
                 'hardly', 'scarcely', 'rarely', 'seldom', 'neither', 'nor']

The following function defines a new feature set that expands upon the bag of words feature set. This function goes through each review identifying the word features, but if a word is identified as following one of the negation words as defined above, then it will be added as a negated word feature instead.

In [64]:
#Defining the NOT featureset function
def NOT_features(document, word_features, negationwords):
    features = {}
    for word in word_features:
        features['V_{}'.format(word)] = False
        features['V_NOT{}'.format(word)] = False
    #Loop through the reviews looking at each word. Identify if a word feature is present
    #in the review and if it follows a negation word or not. It is labeled according to which is true.
    for i in range(0, len(document)):
        word = document[i]
        if ((i + 1) < len(document)) and ((word in negationwords) or (word.endswith("n't"))):
            i += 1
            features['V_NOT{}'.format(document[i])] = (document[i] in word_features)
        else:
            features['V_{}'.format(word)] = (word in word_features)
    return features

Experiment 4: Extended List of Negation Words Classification¶

By extending the list of negation words past the most common words, the model may be able to pick up on more types of negative phrases that it was not able to previously. Hopefully this will help it identify more of the negative reviews correctly, therefore reducing the amount of negative reviews it classifies as positive or neutral and the amount of neutral reviews it classifies as negative.

The following negation words are appended onto the end of the negationwords list. These feature common contractions that would likely occur when someone is writing informally on the internet. So including these words should increase the number of phrases that the model is able to identify as featuring negation.

In [79]:
#The extend method is used to append multiple items to a list simultaneously
negationwords.extend(['ain', 'aren', 'couldn', 'didn', 'doesn', 'hadn', 'hasn', 'haven', 'isn', 'ma', 
                      'mightn', 'mustn', 'needn', 'shan', 'shouldn', 'wasn', 'weren', 'won', 'wouldn'])

Experiment 5: Bag of Words without Stopwords Classification¶

There are many words that would occur in both positive and negative reviews that do not lend any information to the sentiment of the review. For example, it is equally likely that a review would contain a pronoun like "I" regardless of how the reviewer felt about the movie.

Words like "I" are known as stopwords and are generally removed in many text processing tasks. This is because they do not add any context to the text being analyzed due to their widespread prevalance regardless of the content being written about. By removing these stopwords from the most common word tokens and using a new bag of words classification that focuses more on the feelings being conveyed in the review, it may be possible for the classifier to make better predictions.

The stopwords that will be removed is the list of English language stopwords provided by the NLTK package. The stopwords are displayed in the output to make it clear what words are being prevented from having a chance at being included in the most frequent word tokens.

In [94]:
#Saving the list of English language stopwords provided by the NLTK package
stopwords = nltk.corpus.stopwords.words('english')
#Displaying the number of stopwords and what they are
print(len(stopwords))
print(stopwords)

179
['i', 'me', 'my', 'myself', 'we', 'our', 'ours', 'ourselves', 'you', "you're", "you've", "you'll", "you'd", 'your', 'yours', 'yourself', 'yourselves', 'he', 'him', 'his', 'himself', 'she', "she's", 'her', 'hers', 'herself', 'it', "it's", 'its', 'itself', 'they', 'them', 'their', 'theirs', 'themselves', 'what', 'which', 'who', 'whom', 'this', 'that', "that'll", 'these', 'those', 'am', 'is', 'are', 'was', 'were', 'be', 'been', 'being', 'have', 'has', 'had', 'having', 'do', 'does', 'did', 'doing', 'a', 'an', 'the', 'and', 'but', 'if', 'or', 'because', 'as', 'until', 'while', 'of', 'at', 'by', 'for', 'with', 'about', 'against', 'between', 'into', 'through', 'during', 'before', 'after', 'above', 'below', 'to', 'from', 'up', 'down', 'in', 'out', 'on', 'off', 'over', 'under', 'again', 'further', 'then', 'once', 'here', 'there', 'when', 'where', 'why', 'how', 'all', 'any', 'both', 'each', 'few', 'more', 'most', 'other', 'some', 'such', 'no', 'nor', 'not', 'only', 'own', 'same', 'so', 'than', 'too', 'very', 's', 't', 'can', 'will', 'just', 'don', "don't", 'should', "should've", 'now', 'd', 'll', 'm', 'o', 're', 've', 'y', 'ain', 'aren', "aren't", 'couldn', "couldn't", 'didn', "didn't", 'doesn', "doesn't", 'hadn', "hadn't", 'hasn', "hasn't", 'haven', "haven't", 'isn', "isn't", 'ma', 'mightn', "mightn't", 'mustn', "mustn't", 'needn', "needn't", 'shan', "shan't", 'shouldn', "shouldn't", 'wasn', "wasn't", 'weren', "weren't", 'won', "won't", 'wouldn', "wouldn't"]

The following code block looks through the list of word tokens from all the reviews and only keeps each token in the list if it does not appear in the list of stopwords. Therefore any stopword tokens are removed from the list of all words from all the reviews.

In [95]:
#Iterating through the list of all word tokens for all the reviews and removing any tokens that appear on the 
#stopwords list
stopwords_removed = [word for word in words_alpha if word not in stopwords]

A new bag of words is generated by finding the 2000 most common word tokens after all the stopwords have been excluded. This new bag of words will be used as the input for same document_features function used in experiment 2 to generated the feature sets.

In [96]:
#A new bag of the most common 2000 words is generated from the word token list without stopwords
words_freq_nostop = nltk.FreqDist(stopwords_removed)
word_items_nostop = words_freq_nostop.most_common(2000)
word_features_nostop = [word for (word, count) in word_items_nostop]
print(word_features_nostop[:40])

["'s", 'film', 'movie', "n't", 'one', 'ha', 'like', 'story', 'make', '-rrb-', '-lrb-', 'character', 'doe', 'time', 'comedy', 'good', 'much', 'even', 'work', 'way', 'performance', 'funny', 'little', 'feel', 'life', 'never', 'director', 'would', 'may', 'love', 'get', 'enough', 'thing', 'wa', 'u', 'look', 'come', 'bad', 'best', 'could']

Experiment 6: Stopwords Removed and Extended Negation Words Classification¶

In an attempt to improve the results of the previous experiments, their feature sets will be combined together. This way the classifier will be focusing on the content words and have the additional features that mark the word following the negation word as being negated. Maybe this will successfully differentiate reviews with stonger emotions from neutral reviews so the classifier's performance will see an improvement.

First a new list of stopwords is created. This one removes any overlap between the stopwords and negation words from the stopwords list. That way none of the negation words are accidentally removed from the overall list of word tokens from all the reviews.

In [111]:
#Creating a new list of stop words that does not contain those words that also appear in the extended negation words
#list
stopwords_negation = [word for word in stopwords if word not in negationwords]

After removing the stopwords from the list of negation words, the word tokens from all the reviews are filtered. Any word appearing the stopwords list is removed from the list of word tokens.

In [112]:
#Using the new list of stopwords to filter the bag of words generated from tokenized word list from all the reviews
stopwords_removed_negation = [word for word in words_alpha if word not in stopwords_negation]

This new bag of words is applied to the frequency distribution function to create a new list of the 2000 most frequently appearing word tokens to use in the feature sets for the classification experiments.

In [113]:
#Applying the new bag of words to the frequency distribution function to find the 2000 most common word tokens
words_freq_nostop_negation = nltk.FreqDist(stopwords_removed_negation)
word_items_nostop_negation = words_freq_nostop_negation.most_common(2000)
word_features_nostop_negation = [word for (word, count) in word_items_nostop_negation]
print(word_features_nostop_negation[:40])

["'s", 'film', 'movie', "n't", 'not', 'one', 'ha', 'like', 'story', 'make', '-rrb-', '-lrb-', 'character', 'doe', 'time', 'comedy', 'good', 'no', 'much', 'even', 'work', 'way', 'performance', 'funny', 'little', 'feel', 'life', 'never', 'director', 'would', 'may', 'love', 'get', 'enough', 'thing', 'wa', 'u', 'look', 'come', 'bad']

Experiment 6A: Five Sentiments with Stopwords Removed and Extended Negation Words¶

Now, that the modified word features have been created, they are used as input along with the negation words and the five sentiment reviews for the NOT_features function that was used in experiments 3 and 4.

In [114]:

#words but including the extended negation words for the five sentiment reviews

The feature sets are separated into training and testing data using the same 90/10 split as in the other experiments.

In [115]:

classifier_nostop_negation = nltk.NaiveBayesClassifier.train(train_set_nostop_negation)

Lists of the predicted and actual values are created to generate the confusion matrix.

In [117]:
#Creating lists of predicted and actual values to create the confusion matrix

Experiment 7: Word Subjectivity Classification¶

This experiment will use very different feature sets compared to the previous experiments. In addition to denoting the presence or absence of words, these feature sets will be built by assigning sentiment values to the individual word tokens of the review and then figuring out how many positive and negative words are in each review. This subjectivity lexicon was provided during the week 8 lab.

First, the file path to the subjectivity lexicon is loaded. This lexicon is saved within the same folder as this Jupyter notebook so it can be loaded easily without specifying a full file path.

In [128]:
#Saving the file path to the subjectivity lexicon
SLpath = "subjclueslen1-HLTEMNLP05.tff"

To read in the subjectivity lexicon a pre-built function is loaded from another Python program. This program was also provided during the week 8 lab as an easy way to apply this lexicon to a corpus. The program is saved in the same folder as this Jupyter notebook so it can be easily imported.

The subjectivity lexicon is read in to this notebook and saved as SL.

In [129]:
#Importing the Python program that reads in the subjectivity lexicon
import subjectivity
#Applying the function from the Python program to read in the subjectivity lexicon
SL = subjectivity.readSubjectivity(SLpath)

The following function uses the values of the subjectivity lexicon to assign sentiment values to the words of the reviews. If the word has a weak subjectivity along with a positive polarity, it is classified as weak positive. If the word has a strong subjectivity along with a positive polarity, it is classified as strong positive. If the word has a weak subjectivity along with a negative polarity, it is classified as weak positive. If the word has a strong subjectivity along with a negative polarity, it is classified as strong negative. As each word is classified into one of the four groups, a corresponding count for that group is increased by 1. After going through all the words, overall positive and negative counts for each will be created by giving twice the weight to the strong sentiment words as the weak sentiment words. This function also includes the True/False values based on the presence or absence of the most common word tokens in the reviews as well.

The classifier will make its decisions based on the True/False values from the most common word tokens and how much more positive or negative each review is according to the calculated counts.

In [130]:
#Defining the SL_features function that will create feature sets based on the bag of words and the sentiment values
#from the lexicon
def SL_features(document, word_features, SL):
    document_words = set(document)
    features = {}
    #Assigning True/False values based on the presence or absence of the most common word tokens in the review
    for word in word_features:
        features['V_{}'.format(word)] = (word in document_words)
    # Initializing counts of the four sentiments categories for the word tokens
    weakPos = 0
    strongPos = 0
    weakNeg = 0
    strongNeg = 0
    #Looping through the words 
    for word in document_words:
        #If the word appears in the sentiment lexicon then its strength and polarity are retrieved
        if word in SL:
            strength, posTag, isStemmed, polarity = SL[word]
            #Depending on the values from the sentiment lexicon, the word is identified as belonging to one of the
            #following 4 categories and the corresponding count is incremented
            if strength == 'weaksubj' and polarity == 'positive':
                weakPos += 1
            if strength == 'strongsubj' and polarity == 'positive':
                strongPos += 1
            if strength == 'weaksubj' and polarity == 'negative':
                weakNeg += 1
            if strength == 'strongsubj' and polarity == 'negative':
                strongNeg += 1
            #Creating features representing the final counts of positive and negative. Strong words are worth twice
            #as much as weak words
            features['positivecount'] = weakPos + (2 * strongPos)
            features['negativecount'] = weakNeg + (2 * strongNeg)      
    return features

Experiment 8: Parts of Speech Classification¶

For the next experiment, the feature sets will be comprised of the number of nouns, verbs, adjectives, and adverbs gathered from the words in each review, as well as an indication of whether the words in the most common word tokens are contained in the review. The classifier will hopefully find similarities in the part of speech distributions between reviews that are contained within the same sentiment category and be able to successfully identify sentiments in the testing data.

The POS_features function is defined below. This function works by using the NLTK part of speech tagger to assign part of speech tags to the word tokens in each review. Once the reviews have been tagged, the function goes through each one and initializes variables that will contain the counts of the number of nouns, adverbs, adjectives, and adverbs in each review. It does this by examining the first 2 letters of the part of speech tags. The NLTK part of speech tagger uses the Stanford part of speech tags which categorizes the same types of part of speech by beginning the tags with the same two letters. For example, singular nouns are NN while plural nouns are NNS. By saying that any word tagged with a part of speech tagged with "NN" is a noun, it will consider all the different types of nouns as the same category. The function will look through the list of word and tag pairs generated by the part of speech tagger for those words in the review that are also in the unfiltered word features and increment the count for the appropriate part of speech as it sees a word belonging to that category. The final counts of nouns, verbs, adjectives, and adverbs for each review are included in the feature sets.

The meanings of all the part of speech tags can be found here: https://www.ling.upenn.edu/courses/Fall_2003/ling001/penn_treebank_pos.html

In [219]:
#Defining the POS_features function
def POS_features(document, word_features):
    document_words = set(document)
    #Tagging the words in each review using the NLTK Stanford part of speech tagger
    tagged_words = nltk.pos_tag(document)
    features = {}
    #For every word in the most common word tokens, identifying that it is contained in the review
    for word in word_features:
        features['contains({})'.format(word)] = (word in document_words)
    #Initializing varibales to contain the counts of words in each part of speech category
    numNoun = 0
    numVerb = 0
    numAdj = 0
    numAdverb = 0
    #Looking at each word and its corresponding speech and incrementing the variable based on which part of speech
    #group that word belongs to
    for (word, tag) in tagged_words:
        if tag.startswith('NN'): numNoun += 1
        if tag.startswith('VB'): numVerb += 1
        if tag.startswith('JJ'): numAdj += 1
        if tag.startswith('RB'): numAdverb += 1
    #The final counts of the parts of speech for each review are included as features in the feature sets
    features['nouns'] = numNoun
    features['verbs'] = numVerb
    features['adjectives'] = numAdj
    features['adverbs'] = numAdverb
    return features

Experiment 9: Textblob Sentiment Analysis¶

For this experiment we will move on from the NLTK package and creating feature sets to see how a pre-trained sentiment classification model does when applied to the reviews. To give this classifier the best chance at being successful, its classifications will be compared to the modified three sentiment labels.

This experiment uses the textblob package. The TextBlob function will be used to convert the text of each review into a blob object. These blob objects contain many pieces of information that can be called with various methods including part of speech tags, part of speech phrases, and subjectivity and polarity sentiment scores. Once the reviews have been converted to blobs, their polarity sentiment scores will be gathered in a list. These scores range from -1 to 1 where -1 is the most negative, 0 is neutral, and 1 is the most positive. The TextBlob sentiment scores will be compared to the three sentiment labels on the reviews to determine if TextBlob matched the review's actual sentiment or not. Matches will be determined in the following way:

  • If the TextBlob score is greater than 0.05 it will classified as at least "somewhat positive" and match to the positive sentiment
  • If the TextBlob score is between -0.05 and 0.05 it will be classified as neutral and match to the neutral sentiment. A small error band is provided since it is unreasonable to think all neutral reviews would score a perfect 0
  • If the TextBlob score is less than -0.05 it will be classified as at least "somewhat negative" and match to the positive sentiment

After creating a list of all the matches and not matches, an "accuracy" will be produced for the TextBlob sentiment analysis by dividing the number of matches by the number of reviews that were analyzed.

The required TextBlob function is imported from the textblob package.

In [165]:
#Importing TextBlob from the textblob package
from textblob import TextBlob

The list of reviews before they were tokenized is copied for use in this experiment. No tokenization or processing is required for the TextBlob function. The TextBlob object is able to produce many different pieces of information about the text from just the single string.

The list of reviews is looped over and each review is individually converted to a text blob object. The first 5 blobs are displayed as the output.

In [247]:
#Copying the review_list into a new list that will be used to convert to TextBlob objects
reviews_for_blobs = review_list.copy()
#Initializing an empty list to hold the text blobs
review_blobs = []
#Looping over each review in the list and appending the TextBlob versions of the reviews to the new list
for review in reviews_for_blobs:
    review_blobs.append(TextBlob(review))
#Displaying the first 5 review blobs
print(review_blobs[:5])

[TextBlob("A series of escapades demonstrating the adage that what is good for the goose is also good for the gander , some of which occasionally amuses but none of which amounts to much of a story ."), TextBlob("This quiet , introspective and entertaining independent is worth seeking ."), TextBlob("Even fans of Ismail Merchant 's work , I suspect , would have a hard time sitting through this one ."), TextBlob("A positively thrilling combination of ethnography and all the intrigue , betrayal , deceit and murder of a Shakespearean tragedy or a juicy soap opera ."), TextBlob("Aggressive self-glorification and a manipulative whitewash .")]

Next, the empty list that will contain the sentiment scores is initialized. A for loop is used to run through every blob and collect the associated sentiment polarity score from each. The first 10 polarity scores are displayed as the output.

In [248]:

#Looping over each review blob, calculating its sentiment polarity score, and appending it to the initialized list

    sentiment_scores.append(review.sentiment.polarity)

The following code block defines the sentiment matcher function. This function will take the lists of sentiment labels and TextBlob sentiment scores as input and return either "Match" or "No Match" for each comparison. The rules for matching are as they were described previously:

  • If the TextBlob score is greater than 0.05 it will classified as at least "somewhat positive" and match to the positive sentiment
  • If the TextBlob score is between -0.05 and 0.05 it will be classified as neutral and match to the neutral sentiment.
  • If the TextBlob score is less than -0.05 it will be classified as at least "somewhat negative" and match to the positive sentiment

A value of "No Match" is returned when none of the three match conditions are met by a label and score pair.

In [275]:
#Defining the sentiment matcher function. This function takes two inputs, the first is intended to be the labeled 
#sentiment, and the second is the TextBlob calculated sentiment score

#If the labeled sentiment is negative and the TextBlob sentiment is less than -0.1 then it is classified as a match
#If the labeled sentiment is neutral and the TextBlob sentiment is between -0.1 and 0.1 then it is classified as a
#match
#If the labeled sentiment is positive and the TextBlob sentiment is greater than 0.1 then it is classified as a match
#If the two inputs meet none of those conditions, it is classified as not a match
def sentiment_matcher(x, y):
    if x == 1 and y < 0.05:
        value = "Match"
    elif x == 2 and (y > -0.05 and y < 0.05):
        value = "Match"
    elif x == 3 and y > 0.05:
        value = "Match"
    else:
        value = "No Match"
    return(value)

An empty column is created in the data frame that will hold the values describing whether the sentiment labels and scores matched or did not match. The sentiment_matcher function is applied to the columns of the data frame containing the sentiment labels and the TextBlob sentiment scores. The function compares the two values in each row, one row at a time, and places the appropriate value in the Sentiment_Match column of that row.

In [308]:
%%capture --no-display

#Creating an empty column in the data frame that will hold the match values
sentiment_comparison_df["Sentiment_Match"] = ''

#Applying the sentiment_matcher to the sentiment labels and the TextBlob sentiment scores in each row of the dataframe
for i in range(len(sentiment_comparison_df)):
    sentiment_comparison_df["Sentiment_Match"][i] = sentiment_matcher(sentiment_comparison_df["Sentiment"][i], 
                                                                       sentiment_comparison_df["Blob Sentiment"][i])

The data frame is displayed and now shows the match value column.

It should be noted that this is not so much a true accuracy as it was a convenient way to summarize the results of this experiment. The accuracy could be "gamed" by adjusting the score interval that corresponds with a neutral sentiment label. The main takeaway is that even the pre-trained model disagrees with the labeled sentiments a good portion of the time.

Experiment 10: Combining Multiple Feature Sets¶

We will return to the NTLK sentiment analyses to try to give the Naive Bayes classifier an even better chance at having improved performance. For this experiment we will combine many of the feature sets functions together to make a feature set containing the word features, the negation word features, the part of speech tag counts, and the subjectivity counts. By combining all the features together we can see if we can force the classifier into having enough information to make better predictions.

This function generates

  • the features using the most common 2000 word tokens from the unfiltered bag of words
  • the features identifying the negation of a word token using the extended list of negation words
  • the features providing the counts of how many nouns, verbs, adjectives, and adverbs are in each review
  • the features providing the weighted counts of positive and negative words in each review
In [323]:
#Defining the multi_features function which combines aspects of various other functions used in this analysis
def multi_features(document, word_features, negationwords, SL):
    features = {}
    document_words = set(document)
    #This function applies the part of speech tagger to the word tokens
    tagged_words = nltk.pos_tag(document)
    #This function indicates whether one of the most common word tokens appears in the review along with the 
    # indication of being negated by one of the words in the extended negation words list
    for word in word_features:
        features['V_{}'.format(word)] = False
        features['V_NOT{}'.format(word)] = False
    for i in range(0, len(document)):
        word = document[i]
        if ((i + 1) < len(document)) and ((word in negationwords) or (word.endswith("n't"))):
            i += 1
            features['V_NOT{}'.format(document[i])] = (document[i] in word_features)
        else:
            features['V_{}'.format(word)] = (word in word_features)
    #This function also includes the part of speech tag counts as features
    for word in word_features:
        features['contains({})'.format(word)] = (word in document_words)
    numNoun = 0
    numVerb = 0
    numAdj = 0
    numAdverb = 0
    for (word, tag) in tagged_words:
        if tag.startswith('NN'): numNoun += 1
        if tag.startswith('VB'): numVerb += 1
        if tag.startswith('JJ'): numAdj += 1
        if tag.startswith('RB'): numAdverb += 1
    features['nouns'] = numNoun
    features['verbs'] = numVerb
    features['adjectives'] = numAdj
    features['adverbs'] = numAdverb

    #Lastly this function also includes the positive and negative count features
    weakPos = 0
    strongPos = 0
    weakNeg = 0
    strongNeg = 0
    for word in document_words:
        if word in SL:
            strength, posTag, isStemmed, polarity = SL[word]
            if strength == 'weaksubj' and polarity == 'positive':
                weakPos += 1
            if strength == 'strongsubj' and polarity == 'positive':
                strongPos += 1
            if strength == 'weaksubj' and polarity == 'negative':
                weakNeg += 1
            if strength == 'strongsubj' and polarity == 'negative':
                strongNeg += 1
            features['positivecount'] = weakPos + (2 * strongPos)
            features['negativecount'] = weakNeg + (2 * strongNeg) 
    return features

Experiment 11: Using the Most Accurate Model to Classify Only Two Sentiments¶

Since all of the classifiers struggled with classifying the reviews with both five and three sentiment labels, one last experiment will be run that takes the best performing classifier and applies it to only reviews that are labeled as positive or negative. The main issue with performance of all the classifiers was the difficulty in accurately predicting the neutral reviews. By removing the reviews entirely, the classification task is simplified and we can see if the Naive Bayes classifier is at least able to handle differentiating between positive and negative. Looking through the results of the experiments reveals that the classifier trained on the feature sets including the positive and negative counts from the subjectivity lexicon performed the best so far. Therefore the SL_featuresets function will be applied to the new two sentiments review data to see what accuracy it achieves.

First, the three sentiments data frame is filtered to remove any of the neutral reviews. The data frame containing only sentiment labels of 1, for negative, or 3, for positive, is displayed as the output.

Each of the tokenized and lemmatized lowercase reviews are now appended with their sentiment label and saved in a new list. Each sentiment label is either a 1 or a 3 since all the neutral reviews were removed.

In [190]:
#Initializing an empty list
lower_posneg_sent = []
#Looping over each row of the three_sentiments data frame and joining each lowercase review with its modified
#Sentiment score and creating tuples
for i in range(len(pos_neg_df)):
    lower_posneg_sent.append((lower_posneg[i], pos_neg_df["Sentiment"][i]))

Like with the processing at the beginning of the report, the reviews are shuffled into a random order before being separated into training and testing data.

In [193]:
#Shuffling the reviews so they are in a random order
random.shuffle(lower_posneg_sent)

Since the list of reviews is different, they are likely to generate a different list of most common word tokens. For this reason, a new bag of words will be created for this experiment. The first step is to tokenize each review and save them in a list.

In [309]:
#Applying the NLTK word_tokenizer function to each review in the review list
word_tokens_posneg = [nltk.word_tokenize(review) for review in review_list_posneg]

Now, the list of tokenized reviews is flattened so that it is one list of all the word tokens from all the reviews.

In [310]:
#Flattening the list of lists, so all the word tokens from all the reviews are contained in a single list
word_tokens_flat_posneg = [word for review in word_tokens_posneg for word in review]

The same processing steps must be applied to the flattened list of word tokens as were applied to list of tokenized reviews above. First, all the word tokens are converted to lower case.

In [311]:
#Making all the word tokens in the flattened list entirely lowercase
words_lower_posneg = [word.lower() for word in word_tokens_flat_posneg]

Now, the alpha_filter is applied to the word token list to remove any tokens that do not contain alphabetic characters. This is so only words are considered for the list of most common word tokens.

In [312]:
#Applying the alpha filter to each word token. If the token does not contain alphabetic characters it is removed
words_alpha_posneg = [word for word in words_lower_posneg if not alpha_filter(word)]

With the non-word tokens removed, the lemmatization function is applied so the forms of the word tokens match the words in the list of tokenized reviews.

In [313]:
#Apply the lemmatization function to all the remaining tokens in Dracula
words_alpha_posneg = [wnl.lemmatize(word) for word in words_alpha_posneg]

A frequency distribution of all the word tokens in the list is created and then the most common 2000 are selected as the basis for creating the feature sets for the training and testing data.

In [314]:
#Creating a frequency distribution of all the word tokens in the words_alpha list
words_freq_posneg = nltk.FreqDist(words_alpha_posneg)
#Collecting the 2000 most common word tokens
word_items_posneg = words_freq_posneg.most_common(2000)
#Saving just the word tokens of the 2000 most frequent in a list
word_features_posneg = [word for (word, count) in word_items_posneg]

The feature sets are created using the SL_features function and the most common word tokens that were just generated alongside the two sentiment reviews.

In [315]:
#Creating the feature sets using the word features, subjectivity lexicon, and two sentiment positive/negative reviews
SL_featuresets_posneg = [(SL_features(d, word_features_posneg, SL), c) for (d, c) in lower_posneg_sent]

The training and testing data is split using a 90/10 proportion. Since there are now a total of 6874 reviews instead of 8529, the split will happen at the 687th review. The Naive Bayes classifier is trained on the training data.

In [316]:
#Creating the training and testing data using a 90/10 split. Since there are now only 6874 reviews, the split happens
#at 687
train_set_SL_posneg, test_set_SL_posneg = SL_featuresets_posneg[687:], SL_featuresets_posneg[:687]
#Training the Naive Bayes classifier on the training data
classifier_SL_posneg = nltk.NaiveBayesClassifier.train(train_set_SL_posneg)

The classifier is evaluated against the testing data and its accuracy is displayed.

In [317]:
#Evaluating the classifier against the training data and displaying its accuracy
nltk.classify.accuracy(classifier_SL_posneg, test_set_SL_posneg)
Out[317]:
0.7962154294032023

The classifier trained on the word subjectivity feature sets is much more accurate when applied to the two sentiment reviews. With about 80% accuracy, this is the first time we are seeing a classifier that achieves a level of performance where it would be deemed usable for the task. Since sentiments are so nuanced it would not be unlikely that even a human reviewer might only be about 80% accurate. This experiment lends evidence to the theory that these classification methods work much better in a binary setting where a neutral sentiment is not an option. The neutral option appears to confuse the classifier more than inform it, leading to worse levels of performance.

Lists of actual and predicted values are created to make a confusion matrix.

In [318]:
#Creating lists of the actual and predicted values to make a confusion matrix
goldlist_SL_posneg = []
predictedlist_SL_posneg = []
for (features, label) in test_set_SL_posneg:
    goldlist_SL_posneg.append(label)
    predictedlist_SL_posneg.append(classifier_SL_posneg.classify(features))

The confusion matrix shows us that the classifier perfomed roughly equally well classifying both negative and positive reviews. It mistook a few more positive reviews as being negative than the other way around, but those differences are largely negligible. This classifier shows great promise in its application for classifying the positive and negative movie reviews.

The classifier is evaluated using a 10-fold cross validation and the mean accuracy is calculated.

The mean accuracy is very similar to the accuracy of the single evaluation, landing just under 80%. Two of the folds even achieved accuracy greater than 80%, while only one of the folds had a bit lower accuracy at around 76%. The classifier shows consistent performance regardless of the groups of reviews it is trained and tested on.

In [321]:
#Displaying the precision, recall, and F1 measures
eval_measures(goldlist_SL_posneg, predictedlist_SL_posneg)

	Precision	Recall		F1

Looking at the precision, recall, and F1 metrics show how equally performant this classifier is for both the negative and positive reviews. Since, there is a roughly equal number of each type of review, the F1 measures are quite close to the accuracy level of the classifier. All these results reflect very positively of this classifier and reveal how these methods are able to perform well when applied to a simpler task.

Summary of Results¶

Many of the classifiers throughout the experiments provided the same results. This classification task was very difficult for the Naive Bayes classifier provided with these NLTK based feature sets. It was never really able to achieve better than 40% accuracy when differentiating between five different sentiments. For some of the sentiments on some experiments, the performance was even worse than random guessing. The classifiers were similarly stuck at 60% accuracy when differentiating between three different sentiments. All these experiments showed that the feature sets did not provide enough information to the Naive Bayes classifier. It is possible that this was just a difficult task based on the way the reviews were tagged, or that movie reviews written by just as many different authors may have too disparate of characteristics for a model to learn from. Even the pre-trained TextBlob classifier could not replicate the sentiments that were attached to the reviews. Since even humans will be prone to disagreement when it comes to sentiment, some might feel that the reviews could have been labeled inaccurately and this led to poor performance of the classifiers.

It is also very possible that these methods are just not robust enough to handle a complicated analysis with several sentiments. When the number of sentiments was reduced to 2, the most performant classifier, the one based on word subjectivity, was able to achieve reasonable results. With around 80% accuracy, this is a classifier that could actually be put into production to try to analyze more movie reviews.

The experiments have shown that the methods are best suited for a binary classification. These traditional NLTK methods are possibly better suited only for an education environment to help one learn the concepts of how a sentiment analyis works. Different types of classifiers or more robust solutions powered by deep learning or AI technologies may be more suited to performing a sentiment analysis on these movie reviews.
